channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: Spanish Judge Drops Charges Against 9 Priests in Sexual Abuse Case
item.description: A Granada judge said only one of the 12 people indicted in the case would be tried because the statute of limitations had expired against the others.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Argentine Official Lashes Out at U.S. Over Prosecutor Dispute
item.description: Other countries should not interfere in the case of the mysterious death of Alberto Nisman, Foreign Minister Héctor Timerman said.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN GILBERT

item.title: World Briefing: Israeli Girl Injured in Palestinian Rock-Throwing Attack in 2013 Dies
item.description: The 4-year-old girl, Adele Biton, died after severe pneumonia that relatives said was complicated by neurological trauma caused by the attack.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Syrian Forces Try to Cut Supply Route to Aleppo as Hezbollah’s Role Grows
item.description: Hezbollah declared that it was also fighting in Iraq, a further expansion of the group’s military expeditions abroad.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Greek Bureaucracy, Not Just Austerity, Is an Economic Drag
item.description: Many business owners say relief from austerity measures imposed by foreign creditors will not be enough to reinvigorate growth.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: France Moves to Open Up Sunday Shopping
item.description: The lower house of Parliament is to debate a proposal that would allow stores in tourist zones and other outlets to offer all-week shopping more often.
item.dc:creator: By AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: French lawmakers are considering a bill that would permit retailers in major tourist areas, like the Galeries Lafayette department store in Paris, to open until midnight on Sundays.

item.title: Israeli Inquiry Faults Netanyahus Over Expenses
item.description: A report by the state comptroller detailed expenses for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and his wife, Sara, including $68,000 over two years for grooming costs.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: Reviving the Art of Debate in Israel
item.description: There has not been a political debate between major candidates running for prime minister since 1996.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Float Accident at Haiti Carnival Parade Kills at Least 16
item.description: At least 16 people were killed early Tuesday in the Haitian capital after a man on top of a musical group's Carnival float was shocked by high-voltage wires above the street, setting off a panic in which dozens of people were trampled, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Swiss Museum Unable to Get Gurlitt Art Trove Amid Dispute Over Will
item.description: A cousin has challenged the will of Cornelius Gurlitt, the reclusive son of a Nazi-era dealer who left his father’s collection to Kunstmuseum Bern.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Eurozone Turmoil: Is This the Day of Reckoning for Greece and Europe?
item.description: Longstanding economic imbalances between North and South seem to finally be approaching a breaking point.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL IRWIN
item.media:description: Demonstrating in front of the Parliament building in Athens this week.

item.title: At Heart of U.S.-South African Trade Dispute, a Serious Game of Chicken
item.description: South Africa has long been placing tariffs on American chickens, frustrating farmers, trade officials and members of Congress from the Chicken Caucus.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER
item.media:credit: Matt Roth for The New York Times
item.media:description: Forty thousand broiler chickens occupy one of the three chicken houses at Charles Postles' farm in Milford, Del.

item.title: Despite Ukraine Truce, Battle for Debaltseve Continues
item.description: Both the Ukrainian army and Russian-backed militants said that their soldiers were engaging in pitched street battles in a railroad town in eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: A child played cards in a cultural center being used as a bomb shelter on Tuesday in Mironovka village, near Debaltseve, Ukraine.

item.title: Gaza Journal: Desperation Drives Gazans Over a Fence and Into Israeli Prisons
item.description: An increasing number of young Palestinians have been caught trying to cross into Israel from Gaza since the 50-day war last summer.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and MAJD AL WAHEIDI
item.media:credit: Wissam Nassar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibrahim al-Awawda, 15, crossed a fence into Israel and was promptly captured and soon returned to Gaza. Many Palestinian youths have been trying to cross to escape the poverty in the territory.

item.title: Prosecutor Asks for Charges Against Dominique Strauss-Kahn to Be Dropped
item.description: The case against the former International Monetary Fund chief appeared to fall apart when five of the six plaintiffs retracted their accusations against him.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Modi Condemns Religious Violence in India
item.description: The remarks were widely interpreted as a response to a series of recent attacks on Roman Catholic churches in and around New Delhi, and to recent elections.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Anger of Suspect in Danish Killings Is Seen as Only Loosely Tied to Islam
item.description: Omar Abdel Hamid El-Hussein is remembered as a young man of intelligence who harbored a growing rage against Danish society.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS and MELISSA EDDY
item.media:description: A memorial service for a man killed at a cafe and another outside a synagogue drew a crowd in Copenhagen on Monday night.

item.title: Taliban Attack Kills at Least 20 Afghan Police Officers
item.description: The coordinated assault by four bombers dressed in police uniforms came as officers in Logar Province were filing into the dining hall for lunch.
item.dc:creator: By MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Increasingly Know What They Want for New Year’s: Canadian Lobster
item.description: Canada’s Atlantic lobsters, known for their hard shells and sweet taste, have become a coveted delicacy in China, with record quantities of the live crustaceans being flown into the country for Lunar New Year celebrations.
item.dc:creator: By JESS MACY YU
item.media:description: Lobster being prepared at a hotel in Beijing. Demand for lobster has risen even as the Chinese government has embarked on a frugality campaign targeting conspicuous consumption by government officials.

item.title: Suicide Bomber, Failing to Reach Pakistani Police, Strikes Busy Neighborhood
item.description: A Taliban-linked group claimed responsibility for the blast in Lahore, which went off after the attacker could not to gain entry to the headquarters of the police.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI
